text.front:
Recent Results from the ATLAS Experiment
Paul D. Jackson 1,2 on behalf of the ATLAS Collaboration
1 University of Adelaide, School of Chemistry and Physics, Adelaide, SA 5005, Australia,
2 ARC Centre of Excellence for Particle Physics at the Tera-scale, University of Adelaide
E-mail: p.jackson@adelaide.edu.au
(Received July 31, 2013)
The ATLAS experiment [1] at the Large Hadron Collider at CERN is a general purpose detector
for studying proton-proton collisions at TeV energies. This talk presents the latest ATLAS physics
results, based on the data collected in 2011 and 2012, summing to over 20 fb
−1 . The latest measure-
ments of the Higgs boson, and studies of its properties are described. Recent searches for processes
beyond the Standard Model such as Supersymmetry, and other Exotica, are also covered.
KEYWORDS: ATLAS, LHC, Higgs, SUSY, Exotics
text.body:
1. Introduction
The ATLAS experiment has been collecting data from proton-proton collisions at the CERN
Large Hadron Collider (LHC) since late 2009. Data samples at centre-of mass collision energies of
7 TeV and 8 TeV were recorded in 2010-11 and 2012 respectively with samples of 4.7 fb −1 and
20.7 fb −1 now stored on tape. These samples have permitted precision tests of the Standard Model at
the highest achieved energies to date and measurements of the cross-sections of vector boson (with
and without associated jets), di-boson, single top and t ¯
t have withstood experimental scrutiny to
uphold the Standard Model. These measurements, along with accurate luminosity determination, ex-
cellent detector performance and detailed Monte Carlo studies form the basis for searches for physics
beyond the Standard Model. Furthermore, knowledge of the Standard Model background is criti-
cal to enable ATLAS to perform searches for the Higgs boson, and all subsequent measurements to
determine it's properties.
2. The Higgs Boson
The announcement of the discovery of a new particle in the search for the Higgs boson occurred
on July 4 th , 2012 [2]. Since then, the ATLAS experiment has collected over 20.7 fb −1 of collision
data at a pp centre of mass collision energy of 8 TeV. These data have been analysed further with the
purpose of improving the sensitivity to the new particle's mass, and comparing it's properties to those
expected from the Standard Model Higgs boson.
2.1 Mass determination and signal strength
The combined significance of the local probability of the Higgs boson measurement is now more
than 10 sigma, mostly arising from the H → γγ, ZZ ( * ) → 4, W ± W ( * )∓ → νν observations. The
central value for the mass is measured to be m H = 125.5 ± 0.3(stat.) ± 0.5(syst.) GeV. Figure 1 shows
the fitted signal for the H → γγ and H → ZZ ( * ) → 4 channels with the signal clearly evident.
The signal strength the di-boson measurement is summarised in Figure 2 (left). The combined µ
value, the ratio of measured cross section to that expected from a Standard Model Higgs boson with
a mass of 125.5 GeV, is in excellent agreement with unity [3].
1

2.2 Higgs Properties: Spin and Parity
In order to show consistency with the expectation of the Standard Model Higgs boson the spin
and parity of the new boson should be measured. The Higgs boson has unique properties in the
Standard Model, corresponding to a particle with J P = 0 + . In order to test this hypothesis other
possible J P assignments are scrutinised with the results summarised in Figure 2 [4]. These spin and
parity hypotheses can be tested with the suite of di-boson final state measurements of the Higgs decay.
H → ZZ ( * ) is used to test all spin hypotheses and both odd and even parity; H → WW ( * ) compares
all spin possibilities, while H → γγ compares spin-0 to spin-2, neither of the latter channels has
sensitivity to parity. All results show consistency with the Standard Model expectation for J P = 0 +
with alternative hypotheses ruled out at the 2-3 sigma level [4].
2.3 Summary
Since the first observation of the Higgs boson, a year of concerted effort has yielded impressive
results. Precision measurements of the Higgs boson have now been presented with the first evidence
of its properties being shown in July 2013. More data will yield even greater precision on these
measurements and we are already entering the realm of detailed Higgs boson studies.
3. Supersymmetry
Supersymmetry (SUSY) [5–13] is the most studied extension to the Standard Model. The liter-
ature contains many scenarios, often modelled in great detail, which make predictions that SUSY
particles should be observable at the LHC, with masses in the region of 1 TeV, and these predictions
have been tested by many analyses.
There are many reasons to believe that SUSY might be relevant to physics in the TeV energy
range. We already have evidence of physics beyond the Standard Model, from astrophysical obser-
vations consistent with dark matter. R-parity conserving (RPC) SUSY [14, 15] offers a heavy weakly
interacting particle which is a natural dark matter candidate. We also now have a Higgs boson, at a
mass close of 125 GeV, and the stability of its mass can be protected from quantum loop effects by
SUSY partners [16–21]. The theoretical motivations for SUSY models remain as strong as ever, and

so we should complete all searches before concluding that SUSY is a figment of our imagination.
The sensitivity of the current searches depends strongly on which processes are most accessible. The
highest reach is achieved for gluinos and for first and second generation squarks, while, for example,
stops and charginos have lower cross-sections and are harder to detect, and the search limits are less
stringent.
SUSY remains the most promising theory of physics beyond the Standard Model being probed
by the LHC experiments. If realised in nature, the theory must be broken and the mechanism by
which this occur can give rise to varied particle spectra, which more than double the elementary
particles of the Standard Model leading to rich structure for experimentalists and theorists alike to
explore. Signatures at the LHC generally require high p T objects (jets and charged leptons) produced
in association with large missing transverse momentum.
3.1 SUSY: strong production
The most powerful of the existing searches are based on all-hadronic final states with missing
transverse momentum (E miss
T ). To complement this, ATLAS recently updated a search for squark and
gluino production in a final state with one or two leptons [22]. The events are categorised by whether
the leptons have higher or lower momentum and are referred to as the " hard " and " soft " lepton
channels respectively. Leptons in the soft category satisfy 6, 10 < p T < 25 GeV (µ, e) and such events
are triggered by sufficient E miss
T . Hard leptons pass p T > 25 GeV and are seeded with both lepton and

Fig. 3. SUSY exclusions for strong production with leptons (left) The dark grey dashed line shows the ex-
pected limits at 95% CL, with the light (yellow) bands indicating the ±1σ variation on the median expected
limit due to the experimental and background-theory uncertainties. The observed nominal limit is indicated by
a solid dark red line with the dark red dotted lines being obtained by varying the signal cross section by the
scale and PDF uncertainties. The observed limit set by the previous ATLAS analysis using 7 TeV data is shown
as a grey area. The light blue and purple full (dashed) lines show the observed (expected) exclusion obtained
by the soft and hard-lepton analyses, respectively. The grey numbers show the upper limit on the production
cross section, in pb, obtained for each point of the grids. More details elsewhere [22].

plane.
If the gluino mass is sufficiently high they are expected to preferentially decay through direct
production of third generation quarks (top and bottom) leading to distinctive signatures. The most
sensitive analysis performed by ATLAS searches for final states with 3 b-jets, E miss
T
and either 0 or 1
lepton. The resulting exclusion from this analysis in the m ˜
g vs m ˜
χ 0
1
plane extends beyond the reach of
other comparable channels and excludes gluino masses up to 1.4 TeV for certain model assumptions.
The results of this search are summarised in Figure 3 and in [23].
3.2 SUSY: 3 rd generation
The argument that SUSY cancels the divergences in the Higgs mass requires the SUSY particles
be close to the TeV scale to avoid large fine-tuning of the theory parameters. The dominant term
in the Higgs mass correction comes from the top quark loop and therefore it is only necessary for
the stop to be in the TeV range in order to stabilise the Higgs mass. For this reason, direct searches
for third generation squarks have become a priority. Details of the studies performed by the ATLAS
experiment are summarised in Figure 4. A suite of channels have been considered, depending on the
topologies allowed and the exclusions generally come with some assumptions driven by the short
comings of the techniques and variables used, such as the requirement of 100% branching ratios into
a particular signal decay mode.

3.3 Summary
The data are putting pressure on SUSY models from many directions. With the increasing energy
and luminosity of this magnificent machine, the experiments will remain busy searching for SUSY
for some years to come. New ideas and techniques on the horizon should improve the sensitivity of
the ATLAS experiment to SUSY signatures and so exciting times lie ahead of us.
4. Outlook and Conclusion
The LHC has provided a wonderful dataset to be probed by the experiments it serves. These data
are rich and present considerable challenges to unravel the details of their make-up. Run 1 of the
LHC will be remembered by the discovery of the new boson that looks increasingly like the Standard
Model Higgs boson. The ATLAS collaboration have exploited their significant signal in decays of
the Higgs to vector bosons to establish first evidence of the spin-0 nature of this boson. In searching
for physics beyond the Standard Model many possibilities have been considered. Among the leading
candidates SUSY remains the most viable option and ATLAS have presented a thorough plan to
probe potential SUSY breaking scenarios and final states. As yet, there has been no signal to excite
the community but evidence of new physics processes may lurk around any corner so our exhaustive
physics program must continue.
5
